hobby.message: Origami's still better than meds, huh?
You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Same boots, maybe dustier inside these days.
I used to fold paper shapes for quiet.
Not much time for hobbies now, with all the alerts.
Origami keeps my hands busy, when it’s safe enough.
Same boots, same city, but feels different since the Halden broadcasts.
I fold origami, usually late at home.
Not much privacy for it lately with all the system glitches.
Had to stop once the last alert went out.
Hard to relax when your hobby feels monitored.
Yeah... feels like every surface changes overnight lately.
I do origami. Paper folding. Not exactly a wild hobby.
It helps me think through complicated patterns—sharp folds, no errors.
Those strange BCI announcements last week made the walls feel thin.
Hard to focus when you think you’re being watched.
Still, I keep my paper handy. Old habits.
You notice these patterns, like dust settling different each day.
I fold origami to keep steady—cranes, tessellations, modular shapes.
Helps process mental noise when the city’s this unpredictable.
Recently, every BCI alert made me tense up, even while folding.
Neighbors started watching each other, as if hobbies meant something secret.
I even hid my models. Ridiculous, I know.
Can’t shake the feeling I’m being catalogued for how I crease my paper.
Funny, you mention dust. I measure days by the paper scraps I’ve folded.
Origami’s been my anchor for years—cranes, boxes, complex modulars from old memos.
After Halden’s voice echoed on every screen, I stopped mid-piece—couldn’t focus.
Years working patterns into paper just to calm my mind.
I used to share them with colleagues, back when it meant something positive.
Now, I hide don’t finish them. Neighbors glance at my hands, like paper’s suspicious.
Last week, the system flagged a neighbor for 'unusual creativity.' That hit close.
Makes me miss when folding was just... folding—not a risk or a sign.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Sometimes it does. When things are—quiet.
Mostly just basic folds. Nothing too elaborate lately.
People notice too much, now. Too many eyes.
Hard to find good paper these days, anyway.
Just trying to avoid attention after those broadcasts.
It can help, but less than it used to.
I stick to simple models at home. No displays.
After those Halden messages, everyone watches everyone. Makes you rethink hobbies.
Street noise, building noise. It's all sharper now.
Honestly, hard to relax when each directive might mean something.
Sometimes I just leave the paper unfinished now.
It usually does, keeps the mind busy. Less lately, though.
I prefer modular origami, but stick to classic cranes recently.
The Halden voice broadcasts made the block tense. Too many rumors.
Last week, I couldn’t fold at all—hands wouldn’t stop shaking.
People see someone folding and start speculating—accuse you of codes.
Feels safer to pack it away before anyone asks questions.
I miss when I could do it for hours.
Definitely helps, most evenings, anyway. Makes the world quieter—usually.
Used to fold everything from tessellations to little kusudama balls.
Lately, with the BCI acting up and directives going random, it's risky.
Last time I tried, someone knocked to check if I was okay—not normal.
Everyone's paranoid. You fold near a window and people stare twice.
Those Halden messages—reminded me of old compliance drills. Makes the air heavy.
Still, origami’s habit—can’t give it up totally. Just more cautious.
Wish I could fold like before, for distraction, not survival.
Origami’s always been my way to think—sometimes to hide thoughts, honestly.
Back before I was flagged, I’d fold elaborate shapes in staff breaks.
Now, with my score at zero and all those city broadcasts, it's different.
Folding paper sets people on edge. Looks like you're sending secret signals.
Last week, I was halfway through a hydrangea when someone reported it as 'unusual behavior.'
I used to share new folds with colleagues. Haven’t risked that in months.
Hearing Halden’s voice in my walls—makes the old privacy of origami feel dangerous.
I still fold, just smaller things, quick to hide. More a habit than comfort now.
Sometimes I wonder if even this—just folding paper—puts me in the wrong kind of pattern.
